Šarec poziva Levico, naj preneha s politiko ultimatov
05 Nov 2019, 18:30 by STA

Po sporočilu Levice, da bodo zavrnitev njihovega predloga za ukinitev dopolnilnega zdravstvenega zavarovanja razumeli kot konec sodelovanja z vlado, je premier Marjan Šarec povedal, da si želi nadaljnjega sodelovanja. Levico pa je pozval k prenehanju politike ultimatov. Prvak SD Dejan Židan je prepričan, da koalicija potrebuje partnerstvo z Levico.



Marjan Šarec:  Foto: Leo Caharija

LJUBLJANA > Premier in predsednik LMŠ Marjan Šarec ocenjuje, da Levica zadnje čase žal uporablja neko politiko ultimatov, ki po njegovem mnenju ni najboljša. Kot je dejal, bi si želel še naprej partnerskega odnosa z Levico, ne želi si prekinitve sodelovanja, zato poziva, “da se taka politika ultimatov ne izvaja”. Po njegovem mnenju namreč ta v trenutni politični konstalaciji pa tudi v demokraciji kot taki ni primerna, saj ne more biti vse tako, kot si ena stranka želi.
Strinjajo se z ukinitvijo, različne so le poti do nje
Ob tem je zavrnil očitke, da vlada ne sledi predlogom Levice, in naštel nekatere že sprejete ukrepe, kot so dvig minimalne plače in zagotovitev zemljišč za gradnjo stanovanj republiškemu stanovanjskemu skladu. Ponovil je tudi, da se v koaliciji strinjajo z ukinitvijo dopolnilnega zdravstvenega zavarovanja, “različne so le poti do tja in vlada oziroma koalicija bo vložila svoj predlog, ker menimo, da je bolj finančno vzdržen in bolje naslavlja vprašanja, ki so še na mizi”.
Tudi Židan je prepričan, da koalicija potrebuje partnerstvo z Levico in da je za SD strateškega pomena. Zato je koordinatorja Levice Luko Mesca povabil na skupni sestanek obeh strank.
"Kot predsednik SD si želim, da bi drug v drugem večkrat prepoznali zaveznika za to, da bodo rešitve v Sloveniji v korist ljudem, skupnosti in okolju. Vem, da imamo skupaj izjemen politični, intelektualni in organizacijski potencial," je zapisal v pismu, ki ga je objavil tudi na Twitterju.



Kot je dodal, se zaveda, da je Levica, kot jo poznamo danes, nastala tudi kot odgovor na nekatere napake socialne demokracije. Kljub temu, da se pogosto ne strinjajo v metodah delovanja, pa jih po njegovih besedah povezuje tudi več skupnih ciljev.
"To so nesporno tudi ukinitev dopolnilnega zdravstvenega zavarovanja, bolj pravična obdavčitev (tudi kapitalskih prihodkov), pospešena javna izgradnja stanovanj in ambiciozna okoljska politika," je naštel in poudaril, da je do teh rešitev v tem mandatu "mogoče priti le, če bomo delali skupaj". Zaveda pa se, kot piše, da je za to nujno potreben drugačen način političnega delovanja in sodelovanja, o čemer se želi pogovoriti z Levico.
Mesec: ključna bo jutrišnja odločitev koalicijskih poslanskih skupin
Koordinator Levice Luka Mesec je v pisnem odgovoru Židanu spomnil, da je za nadaljnje sodelovanje med vlado in Levico ključna sredina odločitev koalicijskih poslanskih skupin na odborih DZ za finance in zdravstvo, kjer bosta obravnavana predloga Levice o ukinitvi dopolnilnega zdravstvenega zavarovanja.
Kot je navedel, jih Židanova pobuda za sestanek med strankama veseli in so se pripravljeni sestati z njim, a glede na to, da so danes v pripravah na sredini obravnavi, vabilo pa so prejeli šele pred par urami, organizacija sestanka v tako kratkem času ni mogoča. "V znak želje po okrepitvi odnosov med strankama bi bilo vsekakor dobrodošlo, da jutri na odborih naš predlog ukinitve dopolnilnega zdravstvenega zavarovanja podprete," je dodal Mesec.
Če bo koalicija predlog zavrnila, bodo lahko le še ugotovili, da je vlada s tem dokončno odstopila od sporazuma o sodelovanju z njimi, je sicer danes že dejal Mesec.
text:
Šarec urges Levica to end the policy of ultimates
05 Nov 2019, 18:30 by STA

According to a message from the Left that their rejection of their proposal to abolish supplementary health insurance will be seen as the end of cooperation with the government, Prime Minister Marjan Sarec said he wanted to continue cooperation. The left, however, called for an end to the ultimatum policy. SD champion Dejan Zidan believes the coalition needs a partnership with the Left.



Marjan Sarec: Photo: Leo Cahari

LJUBLJANA> Marjan Sarec, Prime Minister and President of the LMS, estimates that the Left has unfortunately been using some ultimatum policy, which, in its opinion, is not the best. He said he would like to continue to partner with Levica, does not want to break off cooperation, and therefore calls for "such an ultimatum policy not to be implemented". In his opinion, this is not appropriate in the current political constitution, but also in democracy as such, because it cannot be all that one party wants.
They agree to the abolition, only the paths to it are different
In doing so, he dismissed complaints that the government was not following Levica's proposals, citing some measures already taken, such as raising the minimum wage and providing land for housing construction to the Republican Housing Fund. He reiterated that the coalition agrees to abolish supplementary health insurance, "only the paths are different and the government or the coalition will submit a proposal because we think it is more financially sustainable and better addresses the issues still on the table." .
Židan is also convinced that the coalition needs a partnership with the Left and that the SD is of strategic importance. He therefore invited the left-wing coordinator, Luko Mesca, to a joint meeting between the two parties.
"As president of the SD, I would like to recognize each other on several occasions as an ally for the solutions in Slovenia to benefit people, the community and the environment. I know that together we have tremendous political, intellectual and organizational potential," he wrote in the letter, which he also posted on Twitter.



He is aware that the Left, as we know it today, was also created in response to some of the mistakes of social democracy. Although they often disagree on methods of action, they also say that they are linked by several common goals.
"These are undoubtedly the abolition of supplementary health insurance, fairer taxation (including capital income), accelerated public housing construction and an ambitious environmental policy," he said, noting that these solutions can only be achieved if we work in this term together ". He is aware, however, that this requires a different way of political action and cooperation, which he wants to discuss with the Left.
Month: The decision of tomorrow's coalition parliamentary groups will be crucial
Levica Coordinator Luka Mesec, in a written reply to Židan, reminded that further cooperation between the Government and the Left is the key to the decisions of the coalition parliamentary groups on the committees of the Finance and Health Committees, which will discuss the proposals of the Left on the abolition of supplementary health insurance.
He stated that the Jewish Initiative for a meeting between the parties was pleased and willing to meet with him, but given that they are in the middle of a hearing today and received an invitation just a few hours ago, the organization of the meeting in such a short time was not possible. "It would certainly be welcomed to support our proposal to abolish supplementary health insurance tomorrow on the committees, as a sign of a desire to strengthen client relationships," Moon added.
If the coalition rejects the proposal, they will only be able to conclude that the government has thus definitively withdrawn the agreement on cooperation with them, Moon said earlier today.
